trails.title: Biology Basics
trails.desc: Explore the wonders of living things, from animals and plants to cells and life cycles.
trails.subject: science

checkpoints.title: Living vs. Nonliving
checkpoints.desc: Learn how to tell what’s alive and what’s not.

questions.question: Which of these is a living thing?
questions.correctExplanation: Trees grow, need water, and make food—so they are living things!

questions.question: What do all living things need to survive?
questions.correctExplanation: Sunlight helps plants grow and gives energy to all living things.

questions.question: Which of these does NOT grow?
questions.correctExplanation: A chair is not alive, so it doesn’t grow.

questions.question: All living things can...
questions.correctExplanation: Living things move, grow, and make more of themselves.

questions.question: Which of these is nonliving?
questions.correctExplanation: A pencil is made by people and doesn’t grow or breathe.

questions.question: How can you tell if something is living?
questions.correctExplanation: Living things grow and change over time.

questions.question: Which of these living things can fly?
questions.correctExplanation: Eagles are living animals that can fly.

questions.question: Where do fish live?
questions.correctExplanation: Fish live in water where they can swim and breathe.

questions.question: Which animal lives in the desert?
questions.correctExplanation: Camels live in the desert and store water to stay hydrated.

questions.question: Where do polar bears live?
questions.correctExplanation: Polar bears live in cold Arctic areas with lots of snow and ice.

questions.question: What kind of habitat is a forest?
questions.correctExplanation: Forests are home to many trees and animals.

questions.question: Which of these animals lives in a tree?
questions.correctExplanation: Monkeys often live in trees and swing from branch to branch.

questions.question: Where do frogs usually live?
questions.correctExplanation: Frogs live near water so they can keep their skin moist.

questions.question: What kind of home does a beaver build?
questions.correctExplanation: Beavers build dams in rivers using sticks and mud.

checkpoints.title: Plant Life
checkpoints.desc: Understand how plants grow and what they need.

questions.question: What do plants need to grow?
questions.correctExplanation: Plants use sunlight, water, and soil to make their food and grow.

questions.question: What part of the plant takes in water?
questions.correctExplanation: Roots grow underground and pull in water from the soil.

questions.question: Which part of the plant makes seeds?
questions.correctExplanation: Flowers make seeds so new plants can grow.

questions.question: What do leaves do?
questions.correctExplanation: Leaves make food for the plant using sunlight.

questions.question: Which of these is a fruit?
questions.correctExplanation: Apples come from the flower of a plant and have seeds—so they’re fruits!

questions.question: What color are most leaves?
questions.correctExplanation: Most leaves are green because of a chemical called chlorophyll.

questions.question: Where do seeds grow into new plants?
questions.correctExplanation: Seeds grow in soil, where they get nutrients and water.

checkpoints.title: Life Cycles
checkpoints.desc: Follow how living things grow and change over time.

questions.question: Which is the correct order of a butterfly’s life cycle?
questions.correctExplanation: Butterflies start as eggs, hatch into caterpillars, form a chrysalis, then emerge as butterflies.

questions.question: What is the baby form of a frog called?
questions.correctExplanation: Frogs hatch from eggs into tadpoles before becoming adult frogs.

questions.question: What do all animals do as part of their life cycle?
questions.correctExplanation: All animals grow, change, and reproduce during their life.

questions.question: What is a life cycle?
questions.correctExplanation: A life cycle shows how living things grow and change from birth to adult.

questions.question: How do chickens start their life?
questions.correctExplanation: Chickens hatch from eggs.

questions.question: Which animal goes through metamorphosis?
questions.correctExplanation: Butterflies change shape completely in their life cycle.

questions.question: What do plants grow from?
questions.correctExplanation: Plants start their life cycle from seeds.

trails.title: Reading Adventures
trails.desc: Build your reading skills by exploring stories, main ideas, and characters.
trails.subject: ela

checkpoints.title: Story Elements
checkpoints.desc: Learn about characters, settings, and plot.

questions.question: What is the setting of a story?
questions.correctExplanation: The setting is where and when the story takes place.

questions.question: Which of these is a character?
questions.correctExplanation: A character is a person or animal in the story.

questions.question: What is the plot?
questions.correctExplanation: The plot is the sequence of events in the story.

questions.question: Who is usually the main character?
answers: The person the story is mostly about
questions.correctExplanation: The main character is the one the story focuses on.

questions.question: What is the problem in a story called?
questions.correctExplanation: The conflict is the problem the characters face.

questions.question: The setting helps readers...
questions.correctExplanation: The setting helps readers picture the story’s world.

questions.question: Which is an example of a plot?
questions.correctExplanation: A plot is a series of events like the princess saving her kingdom.

checkpoints.title: Main Idea
checkpoints.desc: Practice finding the big idea of a paragraph or story.

questions.question: What is a main idea?
answers: What the text is mostly about
questions.correctExplanation: The main idea is what the text is mostly talking about.

questions.question: Which sentence shows a main idea?
answers: Apples are a fruit that grow on trees.
questions.correctExplanation: That sentence tells a big fact about apples, not just an opinion.

questions.question: What helps support a main idea?
questions.correctExplanation: Supporting details give more information about the main idea.

questions.question: Which is a detail, not a main idea?
questions.correctExplanation: Flying south is a specific detail that supports the bigger idea.

questions.question: What might be the main idea of a story about a dog learning tricks?
answers: Dogs are fun to play with.
questions.correctExplanation: That sentence gives a lesson or main message about the story.

questions.question: How can you find the main idea?
answers: Look at the first and last sentences
questions.correctExplanation: The first and last sentences often give hints about the main idea.

questions.question: Why is knowing the main idea important?
questions.correctExplanation: Knowing the main idea helps you know what the story is really about.

trails.title: Math in Nature
trails.desc: See how math is all around us—in patterns, animals, and the world outside!
trails.subject: math

checkpoints.title: Counting in Nature
checkpoints.desc: Use numbers to explore the world around you.

questions.question: How many legs does a spider have?
questions.correctExplanation: Spiders have 8 legs—more than insects!

questions.question: If you see 3 trees with 4 apples each, how many apples total?
questions.correctExplanation: 3 × 4 = 12 apples in total.

questions.question: How many legs do two dogs have together?
questions.correctExplanation: Each dog has 4 legs. 2 × 4 = 8.

questions.question: You see 5 birds flying. 2 fly away. How many are left?
questions.correctExplanation: 5 - 2 = 3 birds still flying.

questions.question: How many petals are on 2 flowers if each has 6 petals?
questions.correctExplanation: 2 × 6 = 12 petals.

questions.question: If you see 4 ants, how many legs do they have in total?
questions.correctExplanation: Each ant has 6 legs. 4 × 6 = 24.

questions.question: What comes after 18 when counting?
questions.correctExplanation: The number that comes after 18 is 19.

checkpoints.title: Shapes in Nature
checkpoints.desc: Find circles, triangles, and more in the natural world.

questions.question: What shape is the sun?
questions.correctExplanation: The sun looks like a round circle in the sky.

questions.question: Which shape is a leaf most like?
questions.correctExplanation: Most leaves are shaped like ovals or teardrops.

questions.question: How many sides does a triangle have?
questions.correctExplanation: Triangles always have 3 sides.

questions.question: What shape do bee hives make?
questions.correctExplanation: Bees make honeycombs in hexagons—shapes with 6 sides!

questions.question: Which of these is shaped like a rectangle?
questions.correctExplanation: Tree trunks often grow tall and rectangular.

questions.question: What shape has no corners?
questions.correctExplanation: Circles are round and have no corners.

questions.question: What shape is a spider web?
questions.correctExplanation: Most spider webs are round like circles.
